name: Microsoft Services
note: this is 'your Microsoft account', not the www.microsoft.com website or the Microsoft Store

points.title: Lawsuit and class action waiver. Arbitration for dispute resolution in the United States

tosdr.tldr: a binding arbitration clause and class action waiver that affects how disputes with Microsoft will be resolved in the United States. This clause governs many of Microsoft's online services - including your Microsoft account and many of their online products and services for consumers, such as Hotmail, SkyDrive, Bing, MSN, Office.com, Windows Live Messenger, Windows Photo Gallery, Windows Movie Maker, Windows Mail Desktop, and Windows Writer.

topics.subtitle: What kind of rights do you give up on?

meta.author: Hugo for “Terms of Service; Didn't Read”
meta.license-for-this-file: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

points.title: Terms may be changed any time at their discretion, without notice to the user

tosdr.tldr: They can change the terms of service any time they see fit, even without notification to the user. Your use of the service supposedly constitutes acceptance of the changes in the terms.

topics.description: Services need to evolve. But it is important that updating the service does not break the consentment with the user. Updates and changes to terms of service and privacy policy need to be properly noticed to users and to sollicit their agreement again.

topics.name: Notice of Changing Terms
topics.subtitle: Are users notified when terms change? Are they given enough time to find out what changed and discuss this with each other before deciding whether to continue to use the service under the new terms?
topics.title: Notice of Changing Terms

points.title: No promise to inform you about data requests from governments

tosdr.tldr: The service has made no statement nor promised users to tell them about data sought by governments, thus not giving you a chance to defend yourself against government requests.

points.title: Transparency on law enforcement requests

tosdr.tldr: The service is making clear to their users what standards and rules law enforcement must follow when they seek access to sensitive user data.
